wordStudies.definition: Love, benevolence, good will, esteem. Specifically the sacrificial, unconditional love of God.
wordStudies.etymology: From agapaō (to love), expressing the idea of a deliberate choice and high value.
wordStudies.theologicalSignificance: Agape is the highest form of love in the New Testament. It is not dependent on the worthiness of the object, but on the character of the giver. It is the defining attribute of God's relationship with humanity and the primary command for believers.
wordStudies.practicalApplication: Seek opportunities to show love that expects nothing in return. Prioritize the well-being of others over your own comfort, as Christ did for us.

wordStudies.definition: Lovingkindness, steadfast love, covenant loyalty, mercy.
wordStudies.etymology: Root meaning 'to bow' or 'to incline' oneself, suggesting a voluntary bending down to help.
wordStudies.theologicalSignificance: Hesed is the core of God's covenant relationship with Israel. It combines the ideas of love, loyalty, and action. It is often described as 'steadfast' because it persists even when the other party is unfaithful.
wordStudies.practicalApplication: Cultivate a spirit of 'steadfast loyalty' in your relationships. Practice mercy that goes beyond what is deserved, reflecting God's never-ending commitment to you.
